cards.front: State the general solution for first-order DC circuits.
cards.back: x(t) = x(∞) + [x(t₀) − x(∞)]·e^(−(t−t₀)/τ). Works for v_C (RC) or i_L (RL). The circuit exponentially relaxes from initial state toward steady state.

cards.front: Time constant for RC and RL?
cards.back: RC: τ = R_TH·C. RL: τ = L/R_TH. Where R_TH is Thevenin resistance seen by C or L.
1. x(t₀): initial value from continuity. 2. x(∞): steady state (C→open, L→short). 3. τ: time constant. Plug into general formula. No ODEs needed.
Steady-state value after all transients die. For RC: v_oc (open-circuit voltage at C terminals). For RL: i_sc (short-circuit current at L terminals).

cards.front: After 1τ, how complete is the response?
cards.back: 63.2%. e⁻¹ = 0.368, so 1−0.368 = 0.632 = 63.2% of the distance from x(t₀) to x(∞) is covered.
99.3%. e⁻⁵ = 0.0067. Practically at steady state. The '5τ rule' is used in circuit design.

cards.front: How to find R_TH for time constant?
cards.back: Turn off all independent sources (V→short, I→open). Find resistance looking into the C or L terminals. Keep dependent sources active.

cards.front: RC charging from 0 to V: what's v_C(t)?
cards.back: v_C(t) = V(1 − e^(−t/τ)). Starts at 0, exponentially approaches V. τ = RC.

cards.front: RC discharging from V to 0: what's v_C(t)?
cards.back: v_C(t) = V·e^(−t/τ). Pure exponential decay. τ = RC.
Same formula: swap v_C ↔ i_L, R_TH·C ↔ L/R_TH, v_oc ↔ i_sc, open ↔ short. Every RC result has an RL dual.
